Sequester.origin: [Anglo-French sequestrer , from Middle French, from Latin sequestrare to hand over to a trustee, from sequester third party to whom disputed property is entrusted, agent, from secus beside, otherwise]

-terÂ·ing.definition: [Anglo-French, from Middle French, from Latinto hand over to a trustee, fromthird party to whom disputed property is entrusted, agent, frombeside, otherwise]

1.definition: to place (as a jury or witness) in seclusion or isolation
1.note: Juries are sequestered in order to preserve their impartiality. Witnesses are sequestered so that their testimony is not influenced by the testimony of prior witnesses.

2 a.definition: to seize esp. by a writ of sequestration
